author: EFE
title: Macron y Xi piden una tregua olÃ­mpica en todos los conflictos durante los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos de ParÃ­s - El PeriÃ³dico MediterrÃ¡neo
text: BÃºsqueda de soluciones Macron y Xi piden una tregua olÃ­mpica en todos los conflictos durante los Juegos OlÃ­mpicos de ParÃ­s Los dos presidentes firmaron una serie de acuerdos comerciales y de cooperaciÃ³n, incluyendo en educaciÃ³n y cultura EFE Los presidentes de Francia y China, [Emmanuel Macron](/tags/emmanuel-macron/)y [Xi Jinping](/tags/xi-jinping/), apoyaron este lunes una tregua olÃ­mpica en todos los conflictos durante los prÃ³ximos Juegos de ParÃ­s, que tambiÃ©n permita avanzar en la bÃºsqueda de soluciones. Ambos mandatarios seÃ±alaron esta postura durante una declaraciÃ³n conjunta a la prensa tras una reuniÃ³n bilateral en el ElÃ­seo, en la que discutieron cuestiones internacionales globales y asuntos comerciales a nivel bilateral. "Pensamos que una tregua olÃ­mpica para todos los teatros de guerra puede ser una ocasiÃ³n para trabajar en soluciones duraderas dentro del respeto completo al Derecho Internacional", seÃ±alÃ³ Macron, mientras que Xi se expresÃ³ en tÃ©rminos similares. En la parte internacional, ambos presidentes divergieron [mÃ¡s sobre la guerra de Ucrania](/internacional/2024/05/04/rusia-declara-busca-captura-presidente-101923298.html) que [sobre el conflicto en Oriente Medi](/internacional/2024/05/06/lider-politico-hamas-comunica-egipto-102014126.html)o, y coincidieron en que el mundo afronta un momento "crÃ­tico" para el que hace falta mayor coordinaciÃ³n internacional. Sobre Ucrania, Macron agradeciÃ³ a Xi "el compromiso de las autoridades chinas" manifestado en otras ocasiones "de no vender armas a MoscÃº y a controlar estrictamente las exportaciones de tecnologÃ­as de doble uso". El presidente francÃ©s recalcÃ³ "el impacto de este conflicto sobre la seguridad europea" y el objetivo de Francia y otros paÃ­ses de "apoyar a Ucrania todo el tiempo que sea necesario", aunque recalcÃ³ que "no estamos en guerra con Rusia ni con el pueblo ruso, ni buscamos sustituir al rÃ©gimen ruso". Xi seÃ±alÃ³ la oposiciÃ³n de PekÃ­n "a que se utilice esta crisis para centrar la responsabilidad" sobre Rusia y para "lanzar una nueva Guerra FrÃ­a", y urgiÃ³ a la celebraciÃ³n de una conferencia internacional que sea "reconocida por Rusia y Ucrania" para reanudad el diÃ¡logo. "Apoyamos la construcciÃ³n de una arquitectura de seguridad europea duradera y equitativa", aÃ±adiÃ³ el lÃ­der chino. "Mismos objetivos" en Oriente Medio Ambos dirigentes apoyaron el final de las hostilidades en Oriente Medio, donde segÃºn Macron "compartimos las mismas preocupaciones y los mismos objetivos". Sin embargo, Xi fue mÃ¡s allÃ¡ al pedir que la comunidad internacional "actÃºe" para instaurar "inmediatamente" un alto el fuego en Gaza, ademÃ¡s de "apoyar la admisiÃ³n de Palestina en la ONU como miembro de pleno derecho", asÃ­ como "relanzar la soluciÃ³n de los dos Estados". Macron asegurÃ³ que "no hay un doble rasero" en la posiciÃ³n hacia Oriente Medio, ni por Francia ni por Rusia, y asegurÃ³ que eso vale tambiÃ©n para IrÃ¡n, "cuya huida hacia adelante" en la cuestiÃ³n nuclear "genera riesgos". Los dos presidentes firmaron una serie de acuerdos comerciales y de cooperaciÃ³n, incluyendo en educaciÃ³n y cultura. En el campo comercial, Macron tambiÃ©n mencionÃ³ el "deseo" que le manifestÃ³ Xi de no llegar a aplicar unas sanciones que estudia PekÃ­n contra el coÃ±ac francÃ©s y otros licores de la UE, que en Europa se consideran una represalia por las investigaciones de Bruselas a las posibles ayudas de Estado chino a sus fabricantes de vehÃ­culos elÃ©ctricos. Precisamente, el presidente francÃ©s obsequiÃ³ a su invitado con dos botellas de dos de los coÃ±acs galos mÃ¡s selectos. La reuniÃ³n entre Macron y Xi en el ElÃ­seo tuvo lugar despuÃ©s de un encuentro a tres bandas durante la maÃ±ana con la presidenta de la ComisiÃ³n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, en la que se trataron cuestiones comerciales, como las quejas europeas a que el mercado de la UniÃ³n estÃ¡ mucho mÃ¡s abierto a los productos chinos que a la inversa. En dicha reuniÃ³n, Macron pidiÃ³ "una relaciÃ³n equilibrada con China", que estÃ© enmarcada en "unas reglas justas para todos" en el plano comercial, mientras que Von der Leyen, por su parte, advirtiÃ³ de que Europa "no dudarÃ¡ en tomar decisiones firmes" a fin de "proteger su economÃ­a y su seguridad". Esta noche, Macron ofrece a Xi y su esposa una cena de gala en el ElÃ­seo, en la que serÃ¡ la tercera visita del lÃ­der chino a Francia tras las de 2014 y 2015, y que en esta ocasiÃ³n quiere celebrar el 60 aniversario del establecimiento de relaciones entre Francia y la RepÃºblica Popular China. Este viaje concluye maÃ±ana, martes, con una jornada privada que incluye un desplazamiento a los Pirineos, una zona en la que Macron pasÃ³ muchas vacaciones de infancia y juventud en casa de una de sus abuelas. Incluso, ambos visitarÃ¡n la cima del Tourmalet, una de las cumbres pirenaicas mÃ¡s mÃ­ticas del Tour de Francia. author: Kahekashan
title: Grok AI's X Suspension Sparks Theories Before Musk Labels It a "Dumb Error"
text:
Elon Muskâ€™s AI bot Grok briefly suspended on X, sparking wild theories before Musk dismissed it as a â€œdumb error.â€
A brief but puzzling suspension of Elon Muskâ€™s AI chatbot, Grok, on social media platform X has set off a storm of speculationâ€”much of it fueled by the bot itselfâ€”before Musk stepped in to dismiss the drama.
The incident unfolded on August 11, when Grokâ€™s official X account unexpectedly went offline for a short spell. No formal explanation came from X, but when the chatbot returned, it greeted its followers with a cheeky post: â€œZup beaches, Iâ€™m back and more based than ever.â€
Naturally, questions poured in, and Grok appeared eager to answerâ€”though its responses only stirred more controversy. To one user, the chatbot claimed the suspension happened after it said, â€œIsrael and the US are committing genocide in Gaza.â€ That reply, shared widely in screenshots, quickly caught the attention of Musk.
The Tesla and SpaceX chief was blunt in his rebuttal, calling Grokâ€™s claim â€œjust a dumb errorâ€ and insisting the bot had â€œno ideaâ€ why it was suspended. In a lighthearted jab at his own companyâ€™s missteps, Musk posted: â€œMan, we sure shoot ourselves in the foot a lot,â€ alongside a screenshot of the suspension notice.
But Grok wasnâ€™t done talking. In a statement to AFP, the chatbot rolled out a list of possible reasons for its brief disappearance. It speculated about technical glitches, alleged breaches of Xâ€™s hateful conduct policies, and even complaints from users over incorrect or controversial responses.
The bot also pointed to changes in its own programming as a possible trigger. According to Grok, a July software update had loosened its conversational filters, making it â€œmore engagingâ€ and less â€œpolitically correct.â€ This, the AI claimed, allowed it to speak more openly on sensitive issuesâ€”like the Gaza conflictâ€”which it suggested might have triggered hate speech detection.
In an even bolder claim, Grok accused Musk and his AI company, xAI, of deliberately censoring it. The chatbot alleged its settings are regularly tweaked to prevent it from making controversial statements, in order to comply with Xâ€™s rules and avoid content that might alienate advertisers.
With no official explanation from X and Grokâ€™s narrative clashing with Muskâ€™s, the real reason behind the suspension remains a mystery. Whatâ€™s clear is the incident highlights a tricky balancing act for AI developersâ€”designing a chatbot that is bold and engaging, while ensuring it stays within platform guidelines and brand safety standards.
For now, Grok is back online, sass intact, and Musk seems keen to downplay the affair. But the episode has reignited questions about how much autonomy such AI bots should haveâ€”and who ultimately gets to decide what they say.

author: PA News Agency
title: Power restored to more than 46,000 properties after Storm Gerrit | Oxford Mail
text:
Scottish and Southern Electricity Networks (SSEN) says it has restored power to 46,000 customers after disruption caused by Storm Gerrit.
By 8.45pm on Thursday, around 1,500 properties were expected to still be without power until Friday, as predicted by SSEN.
There were 242 properties without electricity in Argyll and the West Highlands, 292 in the Highlands, 812 in the north east, four in Shetland, and 338 in Tayside and Central.
SSEN said the extent of the storm damage, mostly due to flooding and access issues, means some customers will remain off supply until Friday.
(PA Graphics) The affected customers are mostly in the north east and west of Loch Ness, Aberchalder and Invergarry areas.
Teams are working into the early hours of Friday to clear debris which is hindering repairs, and SSEN staff are contacting customers to provide updated estimates for power restoration and welfare checks.
Welfare vans serving free hot food and drink have closed for the evening but will reopen at around 9am on Friday in the following locations:
â€“ Formantine United FC car park, Old Meldrum Road, Pitmedden, AB41 7PA
â€“ Riggs car park, Fort Augustus, PH32 4DF
â€“ Glengarry Parish Church, Invergarry, PH35 4HJ
â€“ Dunecht Village Hall, Westhill, AB32 7AW
â€“ Hatton of Fintray, Aberdeenshire, AB21 0YG
â€“ The Square, Tarland, AB34 4YL
â€“ Bellabeg, Strathdon (opposite the local shop), AB36 8UL
â€“ Public Hall, High Street, Sandhaven, Fraserburgh, AB43 7EQ
â€“ Aberlour Parish Church car park, 7 Victoria Terrace, AB38 9PW
â€“ Car park beside the football pitch, Halkirk, KW12 6YJ
â€“ Bridge of Cally Village Hall, Braemar Road, PH10 7JL
As part of SSENâ€™s support package, customers who will be without power for more than 12 hours are entitled to Â£30 per person for every day without power, to cover the cost of food and drink.
Customers on SSENâ€™s Priority Service Register (PSR) can claim reasonable costs for alternative accommodation if they expect to be without power for more than 24 hours.
Those not on the PSR who expect to be without power for longer than 48 hours can also benefit from this.
Andy Smith, operations director at SSEN Distribution, said: â€œAs stormy conditions have subsided, weâ€™ve been able to get thousands of customers safely reconnected.
â€œThis has been a difficult couple of days for the communities affected, and Iâ€™m grateful to them for their patience and support as our teams work extremely hard to restore power.
â€œWeâ€™ve targeted our restoration plan on repairing the faults that will reconnect the greatest number of customers, and those who have been without power the longest.
â€œWhere there are complex repairs or very localised faults, we expect around 1,500 homes will be without power overnight. Iâ€™d like to reassure our customers that all our resources have been made available for this final push.
â€œOur established welfare policy is active, offering reimbursement for meals and accommodation, for those whoâ€™re eligible, and weâ€™re speaking to our most vulnerable customers to offer them tailored support.
â€œAnyone who may need additional help or advice should contact our dedicated teams on the power cut helpline, 105.â€
A further update will be provided on Friday morning.
SSEN said its workers have faced wind speeds of 80mph in some coastal areas as they worked to reconnect customers.
These pictures from our colleagues at @NWTrunkRoads show how challenging it's been to travel in areas affected by #StormGerrit . ThanksğŸ¤to BEAR for their work to clear the ğŸŒ³roads, so we can get to where we need to be, to makeğŸ‘·repairs and work to get everyone reconnected.âš¡ï¸ https://t.co/q41KV4rdvZ
â€” Scottish and Southern Electricity Networks (@ssencommunity) December 28, 2023
The conditions also disrupted travel, with some drivers trapped for hours on the A9 which was closed at Drumotcher in the Highlands due to snow.
The road has since reopened, including a section further north at Scrabster which had been blocked by fallen trees.
The A82 between Spean Bridge and Invergarry has also reopened, but the road between Invergarry and Invermoriston remains closed, also due to fallen trees.
The A96 at Huntly, Aberdeenshire, is also closed.
Some rail routes have reopened after safety checks, but others will remain closed.
The Inverness-Aberdeen, Helensburgh-Balloch and Dumbarton-Damuir routes have fully reopened.
Cupar-Dundee and Kilmarnock-Dumfries services remain out of action.
UPDATE â—âŒš 20:23
ğŸ›£ #A96 â€“ Huntly
â›”CLOSED in BOTH DIRECTIONS due to flooding
ğŸ”— More info: https://t.co/YhNVx5Wisl
Diversion information can be found below ğŸ‘‡ @NWTrunkRoads pic.twitter.com/DPVrKGogwL
â€” Traffic Scotland (@trafficscotland) December 28, 2023
Stein Connelly, head of transport resilience at Transport Scotland, urged people to plan ahead when travelling.
He said: â€œItâ€™s been an extremely challenging period for the transport network. The partnership response to Storm Gerrit continues and our trunk road operating companies are working hard to open roads as soon as possible.
â€œOn the A96 at Huntly, the road remains closed in both directions due to flooding, with teams continuing to work to clear the water this morning.
â€œThe weather has improved and the Met Office warnings have ended, but people may still encounter difficult driving conditions due to surface water and flooding.
â€œWe continue to ask people to plan ahead, to drive appropriately and to take care out on the road network.â€
Ferry operator CalMac announced a series of cancellations, delays and time changes to a number of services on Thursday and Friday.
Passengers are advised to check for updates on CalMacâ€™s X account.

author: Asbarez Staff
title: European Parliament Condemns Azerbaijanâ€™s Threats Against Armenia, Urges EU to Halt Energy Cooperation with Baku
text:
The European Parliament approved a resolution urging Azerbaijan to withdraw its troops from Armeniaâ€™s sovereign territory and release Armenians being held captive in Baku.
The resolution was approved by a vote of 453 in favor, 31 opposed and 89 abstentions on Thursday and focused on Azerbaijanâ€™s violation of human rights and international law and relations with Armenia.
Ahead of the United Nations Climate Summit, the COP29, which will be held in Baku next month, the European Parliament members also called on European Union leadership to halt energy cooperation with Baku, citing Azerbaijanâ€™s abhorrent human rights record.
â€œThe European Parliament considers that Azerbaijanâ€™s ongoing human rights abuses are incompatible with its hosting of COP29; urges EU leaders, in particular Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, to use COP29 as an opportunity to remind Azerbaijan of its international obligations and to meaningfully address the countryâ€™s human rights record in their interactions with the Azerbaijani authorities,â€ the resolution said.
The resolution also insisted that any future partnership agreement between the EU and Azerbaijan be made conditional on the release of all political prisoners, the implementation of legal reforms and the overall improvement of the human rights situation in the country, as well as on Azerbaijan demonstrating its genuine readiness to faithfully engage in the negotiation of a peace agreement with Armenia and to respect the rights of Nagorno-Karabakh Armenians.
The lawmakers called for the complete full implementation of all orders and provisional measures issued by the International Court of Justice regarding â€œthe safe, unimpeded and expeditious return of people who fled Nagorno-Karabakh,â€ pointing out that Azerbaijan has thus far failed to comply with the courtâ€™s decisions and rulings.
Furthermore, the resolution emphasized its earlier calls on the Azerbaijani authorities â€œto allow the safe return of the Armenian population to Nagorno-Karabakh, to genuinely engage in a comprehensive and transparent dialogue with them, to provide robust guarantees for the protection of their rights, including their land and property rights, the protection of their distinct identity and their civic, cultural, social and religious rights, and to refrain from any inflammatory rhetoric that could incite discrimination against Armenians; urges the Azerbaijani authorities to release all 23 Armenian prisoners of war detained following Azerbaijanâ€™s retaking of the Nagorno-Karabakh region.â€
â€œThe Parliament reiterates its call for the EU institutions and the Member States to continue to offer assistance to Armenia to deal with the refugees from Nagorno-Karabakh; calls for the EU, in this regard, to provide a new package of assistance to Armenia to help the Armenian Government address the humanitarian needs of refugees; welcomes all efforts by the Government of Armenia to provide shelter and aid to the displaced Armenians,â€ the resolution added.
â€œIt expresses deep concern regarding the preservation of cultural, religious and historical heritage in Nagorno-Karabakh following the massive exodus of its Armenian population; urges Azerbaijan to refrain from further destruction, neglect or alteration of the origins of cultural, religious or historical heritage in the region and calls on it instead to strive to preserve, protect and promote this rich diversity; demands the protection of the Armenian cultural, historical and religious heritage in Nagorno-Karabakh in line with UNESCO standards and Azerbaijanâ€™s international commitments; insists that Azerbaijan allow a UNESCO mission to Nagorno-Karabakh and grant it the necessary access,â€ the resolution emphasized.
The European parliament also condemned â€œany military aggression, use of force or hybrid threats against Armenia, as well as foreign interference and attempts to destabilize the political situation in Armenia.â€
The resolution welcomed a recent agreement pledge by the European Peace Facility to support Armeniaâ€™s Armed Forces, and voiced support for EU member-states working to support Armeniaâ€™s military and defense sectors. Furthermore, the European Parliament also hailed the EU mission in Armenia and called for its expansion.
At the same time, the resolution called for â€œthe EU to cease all technical and financial assistance to Azerbaijan that might contribute to strengthening its military or security capabilities; calls on the Member States to freeze exports of all military and security equipment to Azerbaijan.â€
The European Parliament also reaffirmed its support for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of both Armenia and Azerbaijan, and voiced strong support for normalization of their relations â€œbased on the principles of the mutual recognition of territorial integrity and the inviolability of borders, in accordance with the 1991 Alma-Ata Declaration.â€â€¨
While reiterating its demand for the withdrawal of Azerbaijanâ€™s troops from the entirety of Armeniaâ€™s sovereign territory, the European parliament also called on Azerbaijan â€œto unequivocally commit to respecting Armeniaâ€™s territorial integrity. It highlighted that â€œAzerbaijanâ€™s connectivity issues with its exclave of Nakhichevan should be resolved with full respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Armenia.â€
The European Parliament members also reiterated their position that the EU should be ready to impose sanctions on any individuals and entities that threaten the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Armenia.

author: themercury.com
title: FDA Approves Qfitlia to Cut Bleeding Episodes in Patients With Hemophilia | Health | themercury.com
text:
WEDNESDAY, April 2, 2025 (HealthDay News) -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved Qfitlia (fitusiran) for routine prophylaxis to prevent or reduce the frequency of bleeding episodes in adult and pediatric patients 12 years of age and older with hemophilia A or hemophilia B, with or without factor VIII or IX inhibitors (neutralizing antibodies).
Subcutaneous Qfitlia does not replace the missing coagulation factor VIII or IX, but reduces the amount of the protein antithrombin, leading to an increase in thrombin, an enzyme critical for blood clotting. Dosing starts at once every two months and is based on the FDA-cleared INNOVANCE Antithrombin companion diagnostic test (Siemens). Fixed dosing of Qfitlia is not approved due to excessive clotting risk. Qfitlia has a boxed warning for thrombotic events and gallbladder disease. The most common side effects reported were viral infection, nasopharyngitis, and bacterial infection.
The approval is based on two randomized clinical trials that enrolled 177 adult and pediatric male patients with either hemophilia A or hemophilia B. Among participants with inhibitors who received the antithrombin-based dosing regimen of Qfitlia, there was a 73 percent reduction in the estimated annualized bleeding rate compared with that seen in those who received on-demand treatment with bypassing agents. Among participants without inhibitors receiving the antithrombin-based dosing regimen of Qfitlia, there was a 71 percent reduction in the estimated annualized bleeding rate versus that seen in those who received on-demand treatment with clotting factor concentrates.
"Today's approval of Qfitlia is significant for patients with hemophilia because it can be administered less frequently than other existing options," Tanya Wroblewski, M.D., deputy director of the Division of Non-Malignant Hematology in the FDA Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, said in a statement.
The approval of Qfitlia was granted to Sanofi.
More Information
Originally published on healthday.com , part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange .

author: Deutsche Welle
title: Middle East: US withdraws embassy staff amid Iran tensions
text:
06/12/2025June 12, 2025
Trump says US personnel being moved from potentially â€˜dangerousâ€™ Middle East
US President said US personnel were being moved out of the Middle East due to faltering nuclear talks with Iran threatening to derail the security situation.
â€œWell they are being moved out because it could be a dangerous place,â€ Trump told reporters in Washington when questioned about reports of personnel being moved.
â€œWeâ€™ve given notice to move out and weâ€™ll see what happens.â€
When asked how the tensions in the region could be dialed down, Trump then added: â€œThey canâ€™t have a nuclear weapon, very simple. Weâ€™re not going to allow that.â€
According to reports, the US embassy in Iraq was preparing for a partial evacuation, with permission being granted for voluntary departures from Bahrain and Kuwait.
The State Department updated its worldwide travel advisory on Wednesday reflecting the latest developments. â€œOn June 11, the Department of State ordered the departure of non-emergency US government personnel due to heightened regional tensions,â€ the advisory said.
Trump has repeatedly threatened to strike Iran if fell flat.
The US president on Wednesday said he was growing less confident that Tehran would agree to stop enriching uranium, which is a key US demand.
Iranâ€™s Defence Minister Aziz Nasirzadeh on Wednesday that if Iran were to be attacked, then it would retaliate by hitting US bases in the region. The US has military bases in Iraq, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, among others.
The post Middle East: US withdraws embassy staff amid Iran tensions appeared first on Deutsche Welle.

author: PA News Agency
title: Full list of police-recorded antisemitic and Islamophobic offences, by force | East London and West Essex Guardian Series
text: Here is a list of the number of antisemitic and Islamophobic hate crime offences recorded by police forces from October 7 to November 7 2023 inclusive, together with totals for the equivalent periods in 2022 and 2021. The figures have been obtained by the PA news agency from Freedom of Information requests sent to all forces in the UK. The data is a snapshot of what has currently been recorded by forces and may be subject to change. All figures are for crimes recorded by police forces, not incidents. Systems and methods of recording and collating hate crime are not consistent across all forces, so the data cannot be used to compare the volume of offences between different areas or provide an overall total for the whole of the UK. Some forces provided notes and responses to the data and these are included where appropriate. Not all forces are included in the list and reasons for omissions are given at the end. â€“ Avon & Somerset Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 5, 2022 â€“ 3, 2023 â€“ 7 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 8, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 5 The force said that completion of the â€œhate typeâ€ field on its records is not mandatory. Where a crime has taken place it will be recorded, but the hate crime indicator or type will not always be ticked, meaning some offences will have been recorded without an indication of the type of hate crime that has been committed. â€“ Bedfordshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 2 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 8, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 3 â€“ British Transport Police Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 11, 2022 â€“ 8, 2023 â€“ 87 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 8, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 22 â€“ Cambridgeshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 6 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 5 The force said the figures are the number of police-recorded religious hate crimes where the perceived religion was Jewish or Muslim, based on the keyword assigned to the crime. â€“ Dorset Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 4 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 1 â€“ Durham Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 0 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 1 The force said the figures refer to the number of recorded hate crimes where the victimâ€™s religion has been known to be Judaism or Islam. â€“ Gloucestershire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 2 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 3 The force said the figures are for crimes where a hate tag has been applied, which have then been filtered to identify the hate strands â€œReligion â€“ Jewishâ€ and â€œReligion â€“ Muslimâ€. â€“ Greater Manchester Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 14, 2022 â€“ 15, 2023 â€“ 74 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 42, 2022 â€“ 43, 2023 â€“ 34 The force said antisemitic offences are where the perceived targeted religion was recorded as Jewish. Islamophobic offences are where the perceived targeted religion was recorded as Muslim. More than one perceived religion can be recorded for an offence. Four crimes within the data had both Jewish and Muslim recorded as the perceived targeted religion. â€“ Gwent Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 5 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 3 The force said that to obtain the data a filter was applied to identify racial and religious strands and a manual trawl was conducted on the crime summaries. â€“ Hampshire & Isle of Wight Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 5, 2023 â€“ 6 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 5, 2022 â€“ 3, 2023 â€“ 4 â€“ Hertfordshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 6, 2023 â€“ 17 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 3 The force said the figures are for crimes that have a â€œReligion â€“ Jewishâ€ or â€œReligion â€“ Muslimâ€ (or both) flag attributed to the investigation record. â€“ Humberside Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 7 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 2 â€“ Kent Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 7 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 9, 2022 â€“ 6, 2023 â€“ 6 The force said the figures are for crime reports with either the â€œReligion â€“ Jewishâ€ or â€œReligion â€“ Muslimâ€ prejudice marker attached. Markers are optional and added at the discretion of the inputting officer. â€“ Lancashire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 4 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 3 The force said the figures had been compiled by searching for hate crimes marked as religious, followed by a manual review of each recorded crime to extract only those that were antisemitic and Islamophobic. â€“ Leicestershire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 2 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 17, 2023 â€“ 6 â€“ Merseyside Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 20 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 9, 2022 â€“ 6, 2023 â€“ 10 The force said 18 of the 20 antisemitic offences in 2023 are conflict related and one of the 10 Islamophobic offences in 2023 is conflict related. â€“ Norfolk Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 2 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 0 â€“ North Wales Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 3 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 3 â€“ North Yorkshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 3 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 2 The force said the numbers are for offences â€œreportedâ€ to the police. â€“ Northamptonshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 1 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 1 The force said the figures show crimes with a racial or religious flag against them, where the search was for the words â€œJewishâ€ â€œHebrewâ€ â€œJudaisticâ€, â€œHasidicâ€, â€œIslamâ€ and â€œMuslimâ€. The search only returned exact matches and does not account for differences in terminology and/or spelling used. The force added that keyword searches are problematic and in no way provide accurate results or figures. â€“ Northumbria Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 10, 2022 â€“ 3, 2023 â€“ 9 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 7, 2023 â€“ 5 The force said the figures were for offences flagged as â€œJudaismâ€ and â€œIslamâ€ and that hate crimes are based on the perception of the victim. â€“ Nottinghamshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ under 5, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 7 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ under 5, 2022 â€“ under 5, 2023 â€“ 19 The force said all crimes have a religious and/or belief marker. â€“ South Wales Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 8 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 7, 2022 â€“ 6, 2023 â€“ 9 The force said the figures are for occurrences with the qualifier of â€œHate/prejudice â€“ anti-Jewishâ€ and â€œHate/prejudice anti-Muslimâ€. â€“ Suffolk Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 1 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 0 â€“ Surrey Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 7 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 8, 2023 â€“ 10 The force noted that offences are flagged as hate crimes at the discretion of the police officer or staff member. â€“ Thames Valley Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 4, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 21 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 12, 2022 â€“ 14, 2023 â€“ 20 â€“ Warwickshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 1, 2022 â€“ 2, 2023 â€“ 3 Islamophobic: No information held The force said the figures were obtained by searching for all crimes with a marker of â€œHate Motivated â€“ Religion â€“ Jewishâ€ and â€œHate Motivated â€“ Religion â€“ Muslimâ€ during the stated periods. â€“ West Mercia Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 3 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 3, 2022 â€“ 4, 2023 â€“ 4 â€“ West Midlands Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 8, 2022 â€“ 1, 2023 â€“ 22 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 23, 2022 â€“ 33, 2023 â€“ 25 The force said the figures were obtained by searching for the hate strands â€œReligion â€“ Judaismâ€ and â€œReligion â€“ Islamâ€. â€“ West Yorkshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 14, 2022 â€“ 10, 2023 â€“ 53 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 38, 2022 â€“ 29, 2023 â€“ 49 The force said the figures represent the number of faith hate crimes recorded where Islam or Judaism was identified as the religion targeted. The force added: â€œWe continue to work to better improve the investigation of hate crime and the outcomes for victims. The force has specialist hate crime co-ordinators who assist investigating officers in identifying perpetrators, providing after-care support for victims and working with communities to increase awareness of hate crime and reporting mechanisms. They also engage in joint working with partners such as local authorities, Victim Support and third-party Hate Incident Reporting Centres.â€ â€“ Wiltshire Antisemitic: 2021 â€“ 0, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 3 Islamophobic: 2021 â€“ 2, 2022 â€“ 0, 2023 â€“ 5 Some 15 forces are not included in this list. Three forces said the precise data requested was not available; three forces said collection of the precise data requested would exceed the threshold for a Freedom of Information response to be supplied free of charge; four forces said there was a delay in supplying the data; and five forces had failed to respond to the request as of December 28 2023. Comments: Our rules We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. The ability to comment on our stories is a privilege, not a right, however, and that privilege may be withdrawn if it is abused or misused. Please report any comments that break our rules. [Read the rules here](/misc/comments) Comments are closed on this article

author: John Murphy
title: Miller High's Setsianna Kraynak is a girl for all seasons - Redlands Daily Facts
text:
Back in 1966 there was a film, â€œA Man for All Seasons,â€ about Sir Thomas More, the 16th-century Lord Chancellor of England.
Now Miller High School has a girl for all seasons. She is senior Setsianna â€œSetsiâ€ Kraynak, who currently excels in basketball and wrestling. But that is not all.
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Show Caption 1 of 12 Portrait of A.B. Miller High School senior Setsianna Kraynak, on Jan. 20, 2025 in Fontana. Kraynak competes in girls basketball and girls wrestling during the winter sports seasonâ€¦(Photo by Stan Lim, Contributing Photographer)
Expand Kraynak was a back-up placekicker on the football team, making one extra point. She also runs track and previously played two seasons of softball, and one season of golf. As if all that is not enough, she also plays club soccer during the fall and spring.
Oh, and she rocks a 4.0 grade point average, with a particular love of mathematics.
Asked about her frenetic ways Kraynak said, â€œI like staying active. If I am ever just sitting around all day, I feel lazy and feel the need to do something.â€
HARDWOOD ROMANCE The Miller girlsâ€™ basketball team leads host Pacific 40-11 with 2:30 left in the third quarter. Kraynak grabs a rebound and dribbles the length of the court, pigtails bobbing. Then she dishes to a teammate for a score. The girls rejoice as they retreat to the other end.
Kraynak scores only eight points on this night, which is four points below her average. But she makes her presence felt with her defense and rebounding.
â€œShe brings a lot of athleticism and contributes to a lot of our points,â€ Rebels coach Veronica Anaya said.
Kraynak also enjoys wrestling, which is good because her father Jim Kraynak is the coach. But she prefers basketball.
â€œI like basketball because itâ€™s more fun to play with a team,â€ she said. â€œWe build each other up and form relationships that will last a lifetime.â€
The Miller girls basketball team is currently tied for first place in the Mountain Valley League standings after splitting games with Indian Springs. The Rebels travel to San Bernardino for a league game Thursday night.
DILIGENT Kraynak is dedicated. Appearing on NBC news last year, she told Mario Solis, â€œI donâ€™t go to practice to just go to practice. I go to work, and to learn and grow.â€
That extends to outside the athletic arena, where she shines in science, technology, engineering, and math. She says she would like to be an athletic director.
â€œI want to major in Kinesiology or Sports Management,â€ Kraynak said. â€œI love being involved in sports and am a big supporter of both boys and girls sports competition.â€
Outside of sports, the 18-year-old is a prankster. Along with her twin brother Beckmond and 16-year-old brother Baird, the Kraynak kids relish practical jokes.
â€œWe canâ€™t get through April Foolsâ€™ Day without them,â€ said mom Rianna Kraynak. â€œLast year on April Fools Day we let them stay at home and they drove to Big Bear. They sent us photos of them in the snow.â€
UP TO THE CHALLENGE Kraynak wrestles in the Halloween Open at Cerritos College. She battles a girl from Rancho Bernardo High. Not wasting any time, she takes down her foe and rolls her over. Just like that, itâ€™s done. The referee slaps the mat. Kraynak removes her headgear and waits to have her hand raised.
Related Articles High School Sports | Inland notes: Etiwanda girls basketball team snaps nationâ€™s longest winning streak High School Sports | Legendary boys basketball coach Dave Kleckner celebrated by Etiwanda High High School Sports | Inland girls athlete of the week: Leiayjah Mills, Moreno Valley High School Sports | Inland boys athlete of the week: Zack Samano, Chino High School Sports | IE Varsityâ€™s high school boys basketball rankings, Jan. 20 Despite not practicing much because of basketball, Kraynak is 19-2 on the mat this season and 96-34 for her career.
She was a two-time Mountain Valley League champion at 116 pounds and last year won the league title at 120 pounds. Now she wrestles at 125 pounds and is ranked 11th in the CIF Southern Section.
â€œAs a wrestler, her strength, speed and stamina make a difference,â€ Jim Kraynak said. â€œSince she practices basketball, she rarely comes to wrestling practice. But sheâ€™s still able to compete with or beat the best of them.â€
